question_text: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for skin lesions on her arms, neck, and scalp.Representative lesions on her left arm are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) (Option B) is the most likely diagnosis. DLE consists of slowly progressive, scaly infiltrative papules and plaques or atrophic red plaques on sun-exposed skin surfaces. Other chronic lesions may be hypertrophic or verrucous appearing. Most patients with DLE, particularly those whose lesions are only on the head and neck, often do not have systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is estimated that 5% to 25% of patients with DLE have coexisting SLE.
